questions.text: A 32 year old fair, fertile and obese patient presents to you with paroxysmal, right upper quadrant pain. She complaints that the pain worsens with deep breath. She also has severe nausea, vomiting, fever and light coloured stools. On examination you found her skin and eyes to be icteric. You suspect her of cholecystitis. A patient of cholecystitis may show referred pain on all of the following structures except?
questions.solution:
Pain of stretched common bile duct or gall bladder is referred to epigastrium, right shoulder and inferior angle of right scapula. Whereas pain on left arm that comes and goes is a possible sign of myocardial infarction

Inflammation of the gallbladder is called cholecystitis. The patient complains of pain over the right hypochondrium radiating to the inferior angle of the right scapula, or to right shoulder. When a finger is placed just below the costal margin, at the tip of the 9th costal cartilage, the patient feels sharp pain on inspiration. He winces with a catch in his breath. This is referred to as Murphy's sign

questions.text: A 30 years old female admitted with complaints of cough, fever and mild dyspnea. RTPCR found to be positive. X-ray shows lung involvement. Which is the most common cause of lung injury in Covid-19 infected patients?
questions.solution:
• The MCC of lung injury in Covid-19 patients is Endothelial Damage
  • The most common finding in lung in Covid-19 patients is diffuse alveolar damage since patients shows features of ARDS in which entire alveoli are covered with hyaline membrane involving total lung tissue.

questions.text: A 63 year old female patient complaints of pain in her right knee. You suspect her to be suffering from osteoarthritis after physical examination. You have advised her for physiotherapy. During followup she complains of pain in her right hip as well after 2 months. What nerve supplies both these joints ?
questions.solution:
The pain in her hip joint is a referred pain from the knee joint. Obturator nerve supplies both the hip and knee joints, and the pain from one joint can be referred to the other. The root value of obturator nerve is ventral division of ventral primary rami of L2, L3 and LA segments of the spinal cord. Femoral nerve also supplies both these joints. Its root value is dorsal division of ventral primary rami of L2, L3 and L4 segments of the spinal cord.

Obturator nerve

It arises from ventral divisions of ventral primary rami of L2, L3 and L4 segments of spinal cord; whereas femoral nerve arises from dorsal divisions of ventral primary rami of the same segments. Adductor magnus and pectineus are two hybrid or composite muscles Since femoral and obturator nerves supply both the hip joint and knee joint, pain from one joint may be referred to the other joint. Obturator nerve is seen at the medial border of psoas major muscle, crosses the ala of sacrum to enter the pelvis. It exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen to enter the medial aspect of the thigh.

Femoral nerve

Dorsal divisions of ventral primary rami of lumbar 2, 3, 4 segments of spinal cord

Thicker in size

Emerges at the lateral border of psoas major

Exits from abdomen by passing deep to the inguinal ligament

Gives branches in the abdomen to iliacus and pectineus

Supplies muscles of front of thigh of, i.e. quadriceps femoris and sartorius. Gives big cutaneous branches.

The tibial nerve provides innervation to the muscles of the lower leg and foot. Specifically: triceps sure (the two headed gastocnemius and soleus), plantaris, Popliteus, tibialis posterior, flexor digitorum longus and flexor hallucis longus. It also has articular and cutaneous branches.

He is a known case of hypertension with irregular compliance to Anti-HTN drugs for 5 years. ECG taken and diagnosed LVH with EF of 40%. All of the following are transduction pathways of the given pathology, expect?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, Pt has cardinal symptoms of heart failure

  • Palpitations
  • Diaphoresis
  • Dyspnea on exertion

Patient is a k/c/o HTN with poor compliance to Antihypertensive drugs which lead to LVH which concomitantly explains heart failure, with EF 40%, due to chronic pressure and volume overload conditions

  • Signaling pathways which trigger hypertrophy activate a set of transcription factors such as
    • GATA 4
    • Nuclear factor of activated T-cell (NFAT)
    • Myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF-2)
  • CARD-MLL 1 (Mixed lineage leukemia protein - 1) is a gene involved in acute leukemia

questions.text: In Traumatic brain injury, which changes in brain metabolism are seen?

choices.text: ↑ CSF Lactate is associated with good Prognosis

questions.solution:
In Traumaticbrain injury

  • Anaerobic condition prevails. So brain cells switch to anerobic metabolism producing increasing amount of lactate
  • Now if this lactate is getting utilized as energy source within brain cells through TCA it is associated with good prognosis (means tissue is recovering from injury),
  • However, if the lactate is not getting utilized in brain cells and it will be exported out from cell in to CSF. This outcome means severe damage to brain cells so that they are not able to utilize lactate. Hence increased lactate levels in CSF are associated with poor prognosis.
  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase activity is decreased due to hypoxic conditions.
  • Now if this lactate is getting utilized as energy source within brain cells through TCA it is associated with good prognosis (means tissue is recovering from injury).
  • However, if the lactate is not getting utilized in brain cells and it will be exported out from cell in to CSF. This outcome means severe damage to brain cells so that they are not able to utilize lactate. Hence increased lactate levels in CSF are associated with poor prognosis.
  • Also, increase lactate uptake from the circulation into brain cells is seen as the injured brain uses lactate as fuel.

questions.text: A patient presented with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, is characterized by skin extensibility and joint hypermobility. Which type of collagen causes these defects?
questions.solution:
• EDS is a heterogenous group of connective tissue disorders that results from heritable defects in the metabolism of fibrillar collagen molecules
  • Caused by deficiency of collagen processing enzymes or from mutation of AA sequences of collagen type I, III and V
  • Mutation of type V collagen results in the classic form of EDS (Skin fragility and extensibility and joint hypermobility)
  • Most clinically severe mutation are in gene for Type III collagen. Potentially lethal vascular problems occur

questions.text: A 27 year old had a meal at 9 pm and records blood glucose at 6 am on the next day which was 182 mg/dL. What is the source of glucose in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The person is fasting for last 11 hours
  • For upto 2 hours after meals, the source of blood glucose is dietary (food) glucose
  • For next 12-18 hours of fasting, liver glycogenolysis will start and is able to maintain blood glucose
  • Hepatic gluconeogenesis will start only after liver glucogen is exhausted (ie) only after 12 hours onwards
  • The end product of muscle glycogenolysis is glucose 6 phosphate, so muscle glycogen cannot maintain the blood glucose. This is due to the absence of enzyme glucose 6-phosphatase in muscle
  • The Enzyme is only present in liver cells ER and is used to convert glucose 6-phosphate to free glucose

questions.text: During a cholecystectomy procedure, the surgeon tries to locate the calot’s triangle to cut off blood supply of which of the following structure?
questions.solution:
Calot's triangle: triangular space formed by cystic duct, common hepatic duct and segment-V of right hemiliver forms Calot's triangle. This space contains cystic artery, cystic lymph node and autonomic fibres reaching the gallbladder

Arteries Supplying the Biliary Apparatus

  • The cystic artery is the chief source of the blood supply, and is distributed to the gallbladder, the cystic duct, the hepatic ducts and the upper part of the bile duct Several branches from the posterior superior pancreaticoduodenal artery supple the lower part of the bile duct
  • The right hepatic artery forms a minor source of supply to the middle part of the bile duct.

The cystic artery usually arises from the right hepatic artery, passes behind the common hepatic and cystic ducts and reaches the upper surface of the neck of the gallbladder, where it divides into superficial and deep branches.

questions.text: In the given option, all of the following are renal auto regulatory mechanisms expect?
questions.solution:
• Kidney shows auto regulation of blood flow
  • Has 3 mechanism
  • Myogenic reflex: Afferent arterioles has smooth muscle in its wall – So as blood flow in glomerulers increases their will be stretch in blood vessel wall – Smooth muscle contract – narrowing of afferent arterioles – regulates blood flow
  • TG feedback: Any changes in blood pressure – Increases in filtration of sodium – excess sodium is reaching thick ascending loop of henle and part of ACT – sensed by macula dense cells – signals afferent arterioles – constriction
  • Ligands involved in signalling: adenosine and ATP
  • Angiotensin II: When volume receptor in renal afferent arterioles are stimulated – prorenin – renin – angiotensin II – Salt, water retention
  • Renal Sympathetic nerves: Causes constriction of arterioles there by changing the blood flow; but it is an external agent

questions.text: Which amino acid results in the disruption of a-helical structure in a segment of mutant protein?
questions.solution:
• Proline disrupts an α-helix because its rigid secondary amino group, is incompatible with an α-helix
• Glutamate, Lysine, Aspartate and Arginine are changed AA and Valine is branched AA
• Note: Charged and branched AA may also disrupt an α-helix because of its low α-helix propensity
• But best option is Proline

questions.text: Cardiac pain is ischemic pain caused by incomplete obstruction of coronary artery. During myocardial infarction due to ischemia people experience pain on the chest and upper left arm. This pain or angina pectoris is which type of pain?
questions.solution:
Referred pain is a pain perceived at a location other than the site of painful stimulus/origin. It is the result of a network of a network of interconnecting sensory nerves, that supplies many different tissues.

The cardiac pain is an ischemic pain caused by incomplete obstruction of a coronary artery.

Axons of pain fibers conveyed by sensory sympathetic cardiac nerves reach T1 - T5 segment of spinal cord mostly through dorsal root of ganglion of left side. Since these DRG also receives sensory impulses from medical side of forearm and upper part of front of chest, pain gets referred to these areas.

Radicular pain is a type of pain that radiates from your back and hip into legs through the spine. The pain travels along the spinal nerve root. This occurs when spinal nerve gets compressed or inflamed.

Neuropathic pain is a pain condition that is usually chronic, caused by chronic progressive nerve disease and can also occur as the result of injury or infection. It is spontaneous, shooting or burning or electric shock like in character.

Somatic pain occurs when pain receptors in tissues (skin, muscle, skeleton, joints, connective tissues) are activated. This type of pain is often described as cramping. Stimuli such as force, temperature, vibration or swelling activate these receptors.

questions.text: The relative refractory period of heart is a time occur during which wave and represent a period when premature beats may lead to fibrillation?
questions.solution:
• T wave represent the repolarisation of the ventricles
  • Absolute refractory Period – The interval from the beginning of the QRS complex to the apex of the T wave
  • Vulnerable period or Relative Refractory period - The last half of the T wave.
    • During this period ventricular fibrillation is often initiated when a premature impulse arrives during this period

questions.text: In which phase of sleep, Sleep terrors occurs?
questions.solution: This disorder occurs primarily in young children during the first few hours of sleep during NREM stage N3 sleep. The child often sits up during sleep and screams, exhibiting autonomic arousal with sweating, tachycardia, large pupils and hyperventilation. The individual may be difficult to arouse and rarely recalls the episodes on awakening in the morning

questions.text: An 8 year old child presents to you with sore throat, cough and fever. On the 3rd day he developed severe symptoms of cough, shortness of breath. You measured his temperature and it is 38 degree C. he also has pain on the right side of chest, right shoulder and peri umbilical region. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is pneumonia of the right lung. The infection from pharynx spread down to the lungs. Pleura consists of two layers, visceral and parietal; the former is insensitive to pain and the latter is sensitive to pain. The costal part of parietal pleura is supplied by intercostal nerves and the mediastinal and central parts of diaphragmatic pleurae are supplied by phrenic (C4) nerve. In pneumonia, there is always an element of pleural infection. The pain of pleuritis radiates to other areas. Due to infection in mediastinal and central part of diaphragmatic pleura, the pain referred to tip of the right shoulder as this area is supplied by supraclavicular nerves with the same root value as phrenic nerve (C4). The costal pleura is supplied by intercostal nerves. These nerves also supply the skin of anterior abdominal wall. So the pain of lower part of costal. Pleura gets referred to skin of abdomen, in the periumbilical area

Pulmonary embolism, tuberculosisand bronchitis has no referred pain presenting as decribed in the question

questions.text: In acute inflammation, which of the following statement is true regrading vasodilation?

choices.text: First affects capillaries and followed by opening of arterioles
First affects the venules and followed by opening of capillaries
Occurs notably due to the action of histamine on vascular smooth muscle

questions.solution:
• Transient vasoconstriction of arterioles at the site of injury is the earliest vascular response in the acute inflammation.
  • This process is mediated by both chemical mediator systems and neurogenic and usually resolves within seconds to minutes.
  • Followed by, Vasodilation then involves the arterioles and then leads to the opening of the new capillary beds in that area.
  • Increased permeability of the microvasculature, with the outpouring of protein-rich fluid into the extravascular tissues.
  • Engorgement of these small vessels with slowly moving red cells, results in stasis
  • Vasodilation is induced by the action of many mediators, notably histamine, on vascular smooth muscle. Vasodilation is responsible for heat (calor) and redness (rubor) at the site

questions.text: The paralysis of gluteus medius and minimus in a person shows
questions.solution:
Lurching gait

It happens because of weakness in your hip girdle and upper thigh muscles. To make up for the weakness, you sway from side to side and your hip drops with each step.

Steppage gait

It is a way of walking that occurs when you have a foot drop. A foot drop is caused by weakness or paralysis in the anterior tibialis muscle. The anterior tibialis muscle usually helps you flex your toes up when you walk. When the muscle is weak, your foot hangs down as you step forward.

Scissors gait.

The steps are slow and small. This type of gait occurs often in patients with spastic cerebral palsy.

Propulsive gait.

It is a stooped, stiff posture with the head and neck bent forward. It may be caused by toxins like carbon monoxide poisoning,Parkinson's disease or certain medications like haloperidol.

questions.text: During your rounds through the surgical ward you found a patient after tubectomy following hepatocellular carcinoma. His neoplasn was to the left side of falciform ligament. According to your opinion which segments would have been removed?
questions.solution:
HEPATIC SEGMENTS

On the basis of the intrahepatic distribution of the hepatic artery, the portal vein and the biliary ducts, the liver can be divided into the right and left functionallobes.

These do not correspond to the anatomical lobes of the liver. The physiological lobes are separated by a plane passing on the anterosuperior surface along a line joining the cystic notch to the groove for the inferior vena cava. On the inferior surface the plane passes through the fossa for the gallbladder and on the posterior surface it passes through the middle of the caudate lobe The right lobe is subdivided into anterior and posterior segments, and the left lobe into medial and lateral segments.

Thus there are four segment in the liver

  1. Right anterior (V and VIII),
  2. Right posterior (VI and VII),
  3. Left lateral (I and III) and
  4. Left medial (I and IV).

The hepatic segments are of surgical importance. The hepatic veins tend to be intersegmental in their course

questions.text: Vision 2020: The right to sight, the global initiative for elimination of avoidable blindness had all of these elements except

choices.text: Setting up strategies and targets for disease control
Setting up financial resource for medical camping
Planning human resource needs and development

questions.solution:
Vision 2020 - The Right to Sight. Global Initiative for Elimination of Avoidable blindness

  • After the realization that unless blindness control efforts are intensified, the prevalence of blindness will double by 2020 AD, the WHO along with an International Partnership committee launched the Vision 2020 Initiative in 1995.
  • Three essential elements of a global plan were set out as follows.

1. Setting up strategies and targets for disease control.

2. Planning human resource needs and development.

3. Addressing infrastructure needs and development. ·

  • Under the global initiative for the elimination of all avoidable blindness by 2020 AD, all countries are commited to a minimum programme. Countries can include other problems than those identified under the minimum programme based on their local situation and needs.
  • The diseases identified for global elimination are
  • The diseases identified for global elimination are

1. Cataract blindness

2. Trachoma blindness and transmission

3. Onchocerciasis

4. Avoidable causes of childhood blindness

5. Refractive errors and low vision

  • Targets have been set up for each of the component diseases for the next 20 years.
  • Above 5 diseases were for global vision 2020. Indian vision 2020 includes following seven diseases.

1. Cataract blindness

2. Trachoma blindness and transmission

3. Childhood blindness

4. Refractive errors and low vision

5. Glaucoma

6. Diabetic retinopathy

7. Corneal blindness

The orphan annie nuclei is seen specifically for papillary thyroid carcinoma. Psammoma bodies and eosinophilic intracellular inclusions are also appreciated.

(a) Howell jolly body is a cytopathological finding of basophilic nuclear remenants in circulating erythrocytes it is mainly observed in megaloblastic anemia vitamin B12 deficiency, liver disorders

(C) Spindle cells are specialized cells that are longer than they are wide. They are found both in normal, healthy tissue and in tumors.

(d) Hurthle cell is a cell in thyroid associated with hashimoto thyroiditis as well as benign and malignant tumors

questions.text: A male patient 32 years of age having a history of recent hepatitis b infection visits your clinic with testicular pain and tenderness, he seems to have lost around 6 kgs recently. His skin looks mildly cyanosed. On auscultation, pulmonary signs are normal. He complains of myalgia and weakness along with dark stools. Lab examination reveals BUN >26mg/dl and the patient is P-ANCA positive. At times he also experiences tingling and numbness in the arms and feet. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) ia characterised by necrotizing inflammatio nof small to medium sized arterial beds. The testicular pain referred in the question is due to the impressive vasculitis of testicular artery. PAN may also be associated with hepatitis antigen, diffuse myalgia and peripheral neuritis. The disease is P-ANCA positive and spares lungs

(a) Consist of triad of focal necrotising vasculitis of lung and upper airway, necrotizing granulomas of upper and lower respiratory tract and necrotizing glomerulitis. But in the question the lung functions are normal and is P-ANCA positive

(b) Microscopic polyangitis can be distinguished from PAN by it’s involvement of smaller vessels (arterioles,capillaries and venules). This also has a pulmonary involvement

(d) Varicocele is dialation of the veins above testicle and is usually harmless. Other systemic manifestations described are not likely to be found

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria produces toxin that works by increasing cGMP ?
questions.solution:
• Enterotoxigenic E.coli produces two enterotoxins- heat stable (ST) and heat-labile toxin (LT).
  • Heat-stable toxin (ST) increases cellular cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) levels, whereas heat-labile toxin (LT) causes elevated cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP).
  • Corynebacterium diphtheria produces toxin that inhibits elongation factor-2 and inhibits protein synthesis.
  • Vibrio cholerae endotoxin increases cAMP and is identical to the heat labile toxin of ETEC.
  • Clostridium difficile exotoxin A and B work by inhibiting protein synthesis.

  • Mumps – 4-6 days before symptoms to 7 days thereafter
  • Rubella – 7 days before symptoms to 7 days after the appearance of the rash

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about bacterial spore are correct?
i) Genus Bacillus and Genus Clostridium form spores in adverse conditions.
ii) The spore forms inside the cell and comprise of part of bacterial DNA, and small amount of cytoplasm surrounded by a thick, keratin like coat.
iii) Once formed, the spores have no metabolic activity.
iv) Formation of spores is also a means of reproduction.
v) Spores cannot be killed by boiling; autoclaving at 121°C, usually for 30 minutes, is required. to ensure sterilization.
questions.solution:
• Spores are highly resistant resting stage formed in unfavorable environmental conditions with low nutrient resources.
  • The spore forms inside the cell and thus is called endospore. It contains the entire bacterial DNA, a small amount of cytoplasm, peptidoglycan, cell membrane and very little water, and most importantly, a thick, keratin like coat that is responsible for the remarkable resistance of the spore to heat, dehydration, radiation, and chemicals.
  • Core contains dipicolinic acid (responsible for heat resistance).
  • Once formed, the spore has no metabolic activity and can remain dormant for many years. Upon exposure to nutrient rich environment, spores germinate into a vegetative cell.
  • Sporulation is not a means of reproduction as one spore gives rise to single vegetative cell.
  • Spores are highly resistant to heat. Therefore, sterilization cannot be achieved by boiling. However, spores of all medically important bacteria are destroyed by autoclaving at 121° C for 15 minutes.

Complications of diabetis mellitus are described in the man.

Vascular disease, neurpathy, nephropathy, glucosuria ,non healing ulcers are all typical symptoms of diabetis mellitus

questions.text: A young man of 25 years of age presents with intense pain affecting the limbs. He is a chronic smoker by history and on furthur physical examination his peripheral limbs are cyanosed, He has resting pain which is burning kind of character, it becomes worse when lying down. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Buerger’s disease or thromboangitis obliterans is encountered in heavy smokers, often before the age of 35 years. It begins with nodular phlebitis, followed by raynaud- like cold sensitivity and leg claudication. The vascular insufficiency can lead to excrutating resting pain and ultimately lead to gangrene requiring amputation

(b) Behcet’s disease is a neutrophil rich small vessel vasculitis. It presents with recurrent oral ulcers ,anterior uveitis, erythema nodosum and recurrent genital ulcers. It is associated with HLAB51 gene and is positive for pathergy test

(c) Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis of medium to large arteries. Also known as pulseless disease due to markedly diminished upper extremity pulses. This disease results in ocular, neurological deficits

(d) Kawasaki disease is seen in young children <10 years of age, presents with febrile illness of >5 days, along with polymorphous rashes, cervical lymph node enlargement >1.5 cm, lip swelling, oral congestion, conjunctival congestion, angular chelitis, edema of distal extremities with desquamation of skin

questions.text: The picture given below belong to which health scheme?
questions.solution:
• Janani shishu suraksha karyakram (JSSK) Government of India has launched Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakaram (JSSK) on 1st June, 2011. The scheme is estimated to benefit more than 12 million pregnant women who access Government health facilities for their delivery. Moreover it will motivate those who still choose to deliver at their homes to opt for institutional deliveries.. It is an initiative with a hope that states would come forward and ensure that benefits under JSSK would reach every needy pregnant woman coming to government pregnant woman coming to government institutional facility.
  • National Health Mission (NHM) It was launched by the government of India in 2005 subsuming the National Rural Health Mission and National Urban Health Mission. It was further extended in March 2018, to continue until March 2020. It is headed by Mission Director and monitored by National Level Monitors appointed by the Government of India.Rural Health Mission (NRHM) and the recently launched National Urban Health Mission (NUHM). Main program components include Health System Strengthening (RMNCH+A) in rural and urban areas Reproductive, Maternal, Neonatal, Child and Adolescent Health, and Communicable and Non-Communicable Diseases. NHM envisages achievement of universal access to equitable, affordable and quality health care services that are accountable and responsive to the needs of the people.
  • National Urban Health Mission (NUHM) It sub-mission of National Health Mission (NHM) has been approved by the Cabinet on 1st May 2013.NUHM envisages to meet 1st May 2013. NUHM envisages to meet health care needs of the urban population with the focus on urban poor, by making available to them essential primary health care services and reducing their out of pocket expenses for treatment. This will be achieved by strengthening the existing health care service delivery system, targeting the people living in slums and converging with various schemes relating to wider determinants of health like drinking water, sanitation, school education, etc. implemented by the Ministries of Urban Development, Housing & Urban Poverty Alleviation, Human Resource Development and Women & Child Development.
  • Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) It is a new initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 'D's viz. Defects at birth, Deficiencies, Diseases, Development delays including disability.

questions.text: A pet keeper male presented to your OPD with yellowish pigmentation of skin and sclera, fever and a palpable mass on his forearm. On examination, you found tender hepatomegaly, spider angioma, splenomegaly and mild pain over his humerus. During auscultation, there is decreased breath sounds indicating obstruction to airway. Your histopathological examination of patient revealed following findings what does this indicate?
questions.solution:
• Hydatid cyst or echinococosis usually presented by pet keepers or farmers is caused by a tapeworm echinococcus granulosus.
  • The image shows hooklets and protoscolex of the parasite during histopathological examination of liver. The patient presents with signs and symptoms of liver disorder.
  • Sometimes the ova on the way to liver enters right side of heart and are caught in pulmonary capillary bed and form pulmonary hydatid cyst, causing various pulmonary symptoms.

(a) Budd chiari syndrome is a condition in which hepatic veins are blocked or narrowed by a clot causing hepatomegaly. This consists of portal hypertension, esophageal varices, ascites, cirrhosis, varicose veins. This histological finding mentioned in the question is not suggestive of budd chiari syndrome

(c) Lliver abcess is mass filled with pus inside liver, common causes are appendicitis or diverticulitis due to hematogenous spread through portal vein. Usg is a preffered diagnostic tool used

(d) TB affects liver in 3 forms: diffuse, granulomatous hepatits, focal/local tuberculoma. The symptoms described in the question is not typical for tuberculosis

questions.text: All of the following are the properties of xenon, an anaesthetic agent except?

Xenon

Advantages of Xenon Anesthesia

1. Inert (probably nontoxic to liver and kidney with no metabolism)

3. Lowest blood solubility (Lowest blood gas partition coefficient) thereforerapid induction and recovery.

Disadvantages of Xenon Anesthesia

1. High cost

2. Low potency (MAC = 70%)

3. No commercially available anaesthesia equipment.

questions.text: A 35 years old male patient presents with the rash on his penis as shown in the image. He describes his rash as very painful and itchy. He also complains of fever, malaise, and myalgias. On genital examination, there are multiple, superficial, tender lesions with erythematous borders. There is firm, tender bilateral lymphadenopathy appreciated in the inguinal region as well. What is the most likely causative organism for this patient’s genital ulcer?
questions.solution:
• The genital ulcers shown in the image point to HSV 2 infection.
  • HSV-2 is found latent in the sacral ganglia. Reactivation of HSV-2 genital infection can occurs frequently, and may be asymptomatic. Even in asymptomatic HSV2 infection, viral shedding can occur resulting in transmission of virus through genital secretions.
  • When symptomatic, local symptoms such as pain and itching, and systemic symptoms of fever, malaise, and myalgias are present.
  • HSV 2 has an incubation period of 2-7 days and primary lesion is vesicular, multiple lesions of 1-2 mm in diameter, superficial, tender and without induration.
  • Firm, bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy may be present.
  • Treatment is with antiviral agents like acyclovir that selectively target HSV DNA synthesis as acyclovir becomes active only after initially being phosphorylated by the HSV thymidine kinase.

questions.text: A young boy presented in OPD with mild itching and irritation of the eyes and eyelids. Eye discharge containing mucus or pus. Under the WHO Vision 2020' programme, the SAFE strategy is adopted for which of the following diseases —
questions.solution:
SAFE strategy developed by the WHO is the key to the treatment of trachoma. This consists of Surgery on the lids. Antibiotics to treat the community pool of infection, Facial cleanliness (SAFE) and Environmental changes Blindness from Trachoma can be stop at four Blindness From Trachoma can be stop at four different points : SAFE

S - Surgical correction for trichiasis. It is a simple operation that can turn out lashes which are scratching the cornea. patients can be operated on in a local dispensary or health center, or other community space if properly prepared. The surgical procedure can be performed by those who have had surgical training : eye doctors, eye nurses or eye care assistants.

A - Antibiotic treatment of people with active trachoma infection.Regular detection and treatment of people with active trachoma is important. The recommended treatment is as follows :

  • Wash the face and clean the eyes
  • Apply tetracycline 1% ointment to both eyes two times daily for six weeks
  • The ointment is sticky and may blur the vision for a few moments. This will only last a few moments. If possible, treat all the children in the family.

F - Clean Faces

Families and individuals can do something to protect themselves from infection by increasing the number of times a child washes Apply tetracycline Ivo ointment to Dom eyes two times daily for six weeks

  • The ointment is sticky and may blur the vision for a few moments. This will only last a few moments. If possible, treat all the children in the family.

F - Clean Faces

Families and individuals can do something to protect themselves from infection by increasing the number of times a child washes his/her face. Regular face washing removes discharge so that flies are not attracted to faces. It does not require great quantities of water: one liter of water can wash up to 30 faces.

E - Environmental Improvement

It is a global initiative to eliminate trachoma as a blinding disease, entitled GET 2020 (Global Elimination of Trachoma), was launched under WHO's leadership in 1997.

questions.text: If mean is 48 and the median is 50 , than the data is said to be
questions.solution:
• Relationship among the three measures of central tendency (ie mean, median and mode) in a skewed curve is an oft repeated question.
  • Lets first see what skewed distribution curve is.
  • An asymmetrical distribution curve can be of two types:

1. Positive skewed distribution curve

2. Negative skewed distribution curve

Positive (or right) and negative (or left) skewed curves are recognized by the location of the tail of the curve (not by the location of the hump - a common error) Positive or Right skewed distribution curve

there curves have a relatively large number of low scores and a small no of very high scores

the mean lies towards the extreme right of the curve Negative or left skewed distribution curve. there curves have a large number of high scores and a relatively small number of low scores the mean lies towards the extreme left of the curve.

Now lets see the measures of central tendency.

  • Mode is the most frequently occurring value it lies at the peak of the hump.
  • Mean is the arithmetic average it is greatly influenced by the relatively small number of very high or very low scores
  • it lies
    • towards the extreme right in a right (Positive) distribution curve and
    • towards the extreme left in a left (negative) distribution curve.
  • Median is the middle value it lies b/w the mean and mode dividing the curve into two equal halves.

Relationship b/w the measures of central tendency

In a symmetrical curve Mean = Median = Mode
In a Positive (Right) skewed curve Mean > Median > Mode
In a Negative (left) skewed curve Mean < Median < Mode

questions.text: The millennium development consists of how many goals?
questions.solution:
Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) is a set of 8 Goals adopted by 189 countries at UN Millennium Summit in September 2000.

  • 3 of 8 goals (Goal 4, 5, 6), 8 of 18 targets and 18 of 48 indicators are 'directly' health related
  • Goal I: Eradicate extreme poverty and hunger
  • Goal 2: Achieve universal primary education
  • Goal 3: Promote gender equality and empower women
  • Goal 4: Reduce child mortality (Reduce by two-thirds the under-five mortality rate)
  • Goal 5: Improve maternal health (Reduce by three-quarters the maternal mortality ratio)
  • Goal 6: Combat HIV/AIDS, malaria and other diseases
  • Goal 7: Ensure environmental sustainability
  • Goal 8: Develop a global partnership for development

questions.text: A single dose of measles vaccine provides life long immunity in the majority of vaccine recipients. But the vaccine, if contaminated can cause
questions.solution:
• Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) occurs while measles vaccine is contaminated or the same vial is used for more than one session on the same day or next day
  • Septic shock is life threatening condition that happens when your bp drops to a dangerous low level after an infection. This can be caused by any type of bacteria. Fungi such as candida and viruses can also be a cause but is very rare
  • Distributive shock is a medical condition in which abnormal distribution of blood flow in the smallest blood vessels results in inadequate supply of blood to the bodies, tissues and organs
  • Allergic rash occurs after measles vaccination in some people even if the vaccine isn’t contaminated

questions.text: Amongst the options listed, which of the following microorganism is paired correctly with the appropriate staining or preparation method used for its recognition?

choices.text: Escherichia coli with crystal violet followed by treatment with acetone
Cryptococcus neoformans in cerebrospinal fluid with Ziehl-Neelsen

questions.solution:
• Potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to visualize fungus in a sample. KOH works by dissolving the host cells and bacteria and spares fungi.
  • Cryptococcus neoformans in cerebrospinal fluid is visualized by India Ink preparation. These yeast cells are identified by large transparent capsules that exclude the India ink particles.
  • Mycobacterium tuberculosis is stained by the Ziehl-Neelsen stain (the classic acid-fast stain). ZN staining is used to identify organisms with mycolic acid in their walls. Mycolic acid in the walls makes the bacterium acid fast and thus they can resist decolorization due to acidic alcohol. Most bacteria with crystal violet and iodine are stained purple in color. Upon treating the stained cells with acetone, gram-positive organisms can retain stain, whereas gram-negative species, such as Escherichia coli, lose the stain, becoming colorless. Counterstaining with safranin is needed to visualize E.coli which stains gram-negative bacteria pink or red.

questions.text: A 24 years old female under MDR-TB therapy comes to your OPD. Which of the following drugs is she resistant to?
questions.solution:

  • It is directly observed therapy certainly helps to improve outcomes and should be considered an integral part of the treatment of MDR-TB.
  • Extensive Drug Resistant TB (XDR-TB) Resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid as well as to any member of the quinolone family and at least one of the following second-line TB treatments are kanamycin, capreomycin, or amikacin

questions.text: Which process of DNA transfer uses a bacteriophage to convert non-toxin producing strains of Corynebacterium diphtheriae to toxin producing strains?
questions.solution:
• Transduction refers to DNA transfer by means of a bacterial virus (bacteriophage).
  • It is of two types- a) Generalised and b) Specialised
  • In generalized type, the lytic phage infects the bacterium and breaks down the bacterial DNA. During packaging of virus particles, the bacterial DNA can accidently become part of the viral capsid. This bacteriophage then infects another bacterium, thus transferring the bacterial genes.
  • In specialized type of transduction, the bacteriophage (lysogenic phage) incorporates into bacterial DNA. When phage DNA is excised, flanking bacterial genes may be excised with it. DNA is packaged into phage capsid and can infect another bacterium.
  • Lysogenic phage helps in incorporating toxins producing genes in non-toxin producing strains like Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Clostridium botulinum, Group A streptococci.

questions.text: In 1918 influenza pandemic was the most severe pandemic in recent history. It was caused by an H1N1 virus with genes of avian origin. Influenza pandemic is mainly caused by which type?
questions.solution:
Influenza is an acute respiratory tract infection caused by influenza virus. There are three viral subtypes

1. Type A can causes all Pandemics and most of the epidemics

2. Type B can cause epidemics

3. Type C can cause endemic infection

Three types of influenza viruses are circulating in world à A (H1N1), A (H3 N2) and B A New type has been recognized A (H5 N1) Mode of transmission is by Droplet infection by respiratory route Incubation period is from 18-72 hours

Clinical features are

  • Most infections are subclinical
  • fever, headache and myalgia
  • Respiratory disease can cause coughing also

Complications

  • Pneumonia mostly caused by streptococcus pneumoniae
  • It worsens with COPD patients
  • Encephalitis
  • Gastric bowel syndrome
  • G I Symptoms can cause by type B virus

Diagnosis

  • Most commonly, the diagnosis is by the use of rapid viral tests that detect viral nucleoprotein or neuraminidase
  • Best specimen is taken from nasopharynx.

questions.text: As a doctor as we are dealing with blood products, syringes etc . It is very easy to spread hepatitis B infection among us but can easily prevented by vaccination. Which is the marker for infectivity of Hepatitis B serum?
questions.solution:
Hepatitis B is a serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus that's easily preventable by a vaccine. This disease is most commonly spread by exposure to infected bodily fluids, by syringes, sexually and mother to baby preventable by a vaccine. This disease is most commonly spread by exposure to infected bodily fluids, by syringes, sexually and mother to baby

Markers of Hepatitis B infection in order of appearance in serum

  • HBcAg - Hepatitis B surface antigen iIt is also known as Australia antigen It is first antigen to appear in serum as it is first evidence of infection It is most important epidemiological marker of Hepatitis B infection
  • HBcAg (Hepatitis B core antigen) It does not appear in serum alone
  • HBeAg (Hepatitis B envelope antigen) It is a secretory form of HBcAg It usually Indicates active viral replication and is a marker of infectivity for Hepatitis B If it persist beyond 3 months, it can be increased chance of chronic Hepatitis B
  • Anti-HBc (Antibody to Hepatitis B core antigen) It is first antibody to appear in serum
  • Anti-HBe (Antibody to Hepatitis B envelope antigen)
  • HBeAg (Hepatitis B envelope antigen) It is a secretory form of HBcAg It usually Indicates active viral replication and s a marker of infectivity for Hepatitis B If it persist beyond 3 months, it can be increased chance of chronic Hepatitis B
  • Anti-HBc (Antibody to Hepatitis B core antigen) It is first antibody to appear in serum
  • Anti-HBe (Antibody to Hepatitis B envelope antigen) It give signals to stoppage of active viral replication And it Indicates end of period of infectivity
  • Anti-HBs (Antibody to Hepatitis B surface antigen) It is the last antibody to appear in serum and gives signals to recovery and end of period of communicability

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD, with complaints of yellowish skin, eyes and mouth. She appears to have dark coloured urine and is unable to handle physical activities. Her history suggests of a recent episode of bloody diarrhea which was resolved medically. On furthur investigation she was found to have a reduced urine output, platelet count-400,00 per microlitre and several bruises on her skin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The classical HUS presents with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia and renal failure. On microscopic examination you may find schistocytes
  • Whereas TTP may present with neurological signs along with hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia

(a) Throbotic thrombocytopenic purpura is due to the formation of platelet rich fibrin thrombi on microvasculature of blood vessels. This occurs due to deficiency of ADAMS-TSB von willibrand factor metalloprotease or Ab against ADAM TS-B

The main features are

1) Microangiopathic anemia

2) Thrombocytopenia

3) Renal failure

4) Fever neurological manifestations

(b) Shigellosis is a bacterial infection characterized by fever, bloody diarrhea, severe stomach cramping or tenderness, dehydration. Symptoms usually begin 1 to 3 days after being exposed to shigella. Shigellosis has not been known to be directly associated with hepatitis

(d) Viral gasteroenteritis - inflammation, swelling, irritation of inner lining of GIT caused by virus. Symptoms usually just a day or two, but may last upto 14 days. Jaundice hepatosplenomegaly or knock pain on the back

(d) Viral gasteroenteritis - this is due to increased hemosiderin pigment in the blood and then later pass through urine. This is seen in incomplete transfusion, G6PD deficiency, PNH, severe burns and certain infections. Not usually typical for diabetic patients

questions.text: A young female presents to your OPD with weakness and pain in limbs, lightheadedness, headache and slight blurring of vision. On examination, her brachial pulse is weak. You have ordered an angiogram in which you found fibrostenotic thickening and occlusion of branches of aorta and subclavian vessels, also there is claudication in limbs. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Takayasuarteritis is a granulomatousvasculitis of medium to large arteries. Also known as pulseless disease due to markedly diminished upper extremity pulses. This disease results in ocular, neurological deficits

(a) Giant cell arteritis is characterized by focal granulomatous inflammation of medium and small arteries, chiefly cranial vessels and most commonly temporal arteries in elderly people. Visual disturbance, polymyalgia rheumatica and flu like symptoms are also seen

(c) polyarteritis nodosa is a systemic disease characterized by necrotising inflammation throughout the wall of various small to medium sized arteries. This is associated with hematuria, albuminuria ,hypertension, diffuse myalgia and peripheral neuritis. Sometimes maybe associated with hepatitis b antigen and deposited immune complexes are the pathogenetic feature

(d) Hyaline arteriosclerosis is typically seen in elderly patients particularly those with mild hypertension and diabetis mellitus. Microscopically there is diffuse, pink ,hyaline thickening of arteriole walls, this is a major microscopic feature of benign nephrosclerosis

questions.text: A 3 year old boy has a history of recurrent pneumonia and multiple episodes of skin infection. He is diagnosed with an immunodeficiency disorder characterized by deficiency of NADPH oxidase. Out of the following options, the child is most prone of getting infected with which organism?
questions.solution:
• CGD [Chronic Granulomatous Disease]
    • Deficiency of NADPHOxidase
    • Leads to recurrent catalase positive infections [Staph & Coliforms]
    • Nitro Blue Tetrolium test à-ve
  • NADPH oxidase is present in the cell membrane of phagocytes like neutrophils that helps in the production of superoxide ion and hydrogen peroxide that in turn are anti - microbial in nature.
  • In CGD, due to deficiency of NADPH oxidase, there is decreased production of H2O2 and superoxide ion.
  • Catalase positive organism have enzyme catalase that degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and molecular oxygen ( H2O2→ H2O + O2).
  • Patients are at risk for infection by catalase ⊕ species (eg, S aureus, Aspergillus) as these bacterium degrade their own H2O2 , making it difficult for the phagocytes to use that H2O2to produce reactive oxygen species for fighting infections.
  • Streptococcus and Enterococcus are catalase negative organisms.

questions.text: A 12 year old boy presents to pediatric OPD with complain of enlarged testis and redness of scrotal skin with slight enlargement of penis. He also complaints of sparse hairs at base of penis. Which of the following is most appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
Tanner’s staging or sexual maturity Rating (SMR) Classification

Stage Pubic hair Genitalia
1 Absent Testicular size < 4 cc or(Prepubertal) < 2.5 cm in longest dimension)
2 Sparse hair, at the base of penis
  • Enlargement of testes & scrotum;
3 Darker, more coarse and curled
  • Further growth of testis
  • Penis increases in length
4 More dense, coarse and curly hair
  • Tests & Scrotum longer
  • Scrotal skin darker
  • Penis increases in length & breadth, glans becomes more prominent.
5 Hair growth extents to inner thighs
  • Adult genitalia (> 20 ml)

IN THE PREPUBERTAL
stage 1 , there may be fine vellus hair that is no different from that found over the abdominal wall.
In stage 2, there is growth of sparse straight hair, primarily at the base of the penis or along thelabia.
In stage 3, hair increases in quantity and is darker and curlier
Stage 4 is characterized by pubic hair that resembles adult pubic hair, although the escutcheon covers a smaller area than seen in adult
stage 5, pubic hair has increased further in volume, spread onto the medial thighs, and taken on characteristic male or female configuration.

questions.text: A 54 old male presented to the hospital with difficulty in swallowing. He also complained pf bad breath and regurgitation of food particles. He is on metformin for his diabetic control. What is the most probable diagnosis this patient is suffering from?
questions.solution:
Zenker’s diverticulum

  • MC type of esophageal diverticulum
  • It is a false diverticulum (mucosa & submucosa)
  • MC in elderly / diabetic / males
  • Inferior constrictor muscle has dual nerve supply
    • Thyropharyngeus – supplied by pharyngeal plexus
    • Cricopharyngeus – supplied by RLN
    • Due to this dual nerve supply – neuromuscular incoordination during swallowing leads to herniation through killian’s dehiscence due to increased pressure

Symptoms

  • MC symptom – dysphagia
  • >50% of cases – Zenker’s diverticula is associated with cervical web.
  • Halitosis
  • Regurgitation

Complications

  • Increased risk of aspiration (due to regurgitation)

↓

Increased of pneumonitis

↓

Increased risk of lung abscess (MC complication lung abscess)

  • Increased risk of SCC (due to chronic inflammation at Zenker’s diverticula)

Investigation

  • IOC for Dx – Barium swallow

Treatment

  • Treatment of choice – cricopharyngealmyotomy + diverticulopexy
  • Other alternative procedures
    • Diverticulectomy (for larger diverticula’s >4 cm)
    • Dohlman procedure

Dohlman’s procedure

  • Aka diverticula-esophagostomy
  • It is endoscopic stapling of septum located between esophagus & diverticula

questions.text: A 35 year old female presents to the emergency on stretcher with severe abdominal pain & diarrhea. She recently suffered from heart attack. On examination, her BP is 90/60 mmofHg and “string of sausages” sign present on investigation. She is suffering from:
questions.solution:
ACUTE MESENTERICISHEMIA

Etiology

1. Emboli (50%)

  • Arrythmia
  • Valvular heart disease
  • MI

2. Arterial thrombosis (25%)

  • Atherosclerosis

3. Non- occlusive mesenteric Ischemia (5-15%)

  • Heart failure
  • Massive burns
  • Sepsis
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Acute MI

4. Venous thrombosis

  • Virchow’s triad (positive)
  • Hyper coagulable state (most important)

↓

Increase risk of mesenteric venous thrombosis

Note: Virchow’s triad:

Clinical feature

  • Severe abdominal pain (MC symptoms)

↓ Characteristic Feature

    • Out of proportion of physical Examination findings
  • Persistent vomiting & diarrhoea
  • Late stage- Shock – hypovolemia, sepsis
  • Melena & haematochezia- 15% cases

Diagnosis

  • Investigation of choice-Mesenteric Arteriography
  • Spasm in the vessel is k/a "STRING OF SAUSAGES" sign is seen on investigation

Management

  • Early diagnosis
  • Aggressive Resuscitation - IN fluids &I/N antibiotics
  • Non-Occlusive mesenteric ischemia
    • Early revascularization - Catheter directed papaverine infusion in SMA, Relieves the spasm of mesenteric vessels
  • Mesenteric venous thrombus
    • Anticoagulants
Patients with
Absence of peritonitis Peritonitis
  • Supportive care
  • Papaverine infusion
  • Anticoagulants
  • Exploratory laparotomy with resection of necrotic bowel

questions.text: Fever and soreness in the right lower leg present in a 15-year-old kid. For the past month, he hasbeen in excruciating discomfort. On inspection, he has a 1.5 cmby 1.5cm red, warm, and sensitive mass in the bottom region of his thigh. An X-ray reveals onion-skin periosteal bone growth. He is suffering from:

questions.text: A 56-year-old patient underwent cataract surgery in your hospital. After 3 days, he presented to OPD with a history of gradually increasing pain and diminution of vision Patient gave an history of initial improvement, but later it went down. Which of the following will be the most likely cause?
questions.solution: Postoperative endophthalmitis is a serious complication that can happen after cataract surgery. It occurs mainly due to invasion of the globe by microbial flora, bacteria, or fungi from the adnexa and environment during the time of surgery. All patients undergoing cataract surgery should be evaluated for any potential risk factors that can enhance the development of postoperative endophthalmitis; managing the intraoperative risk and prophylaxis protocols should be consideredin order to reduce the risk of endophthalmitis. Early follow-up after cataract surgery is highly recommended to detect any sign of endophthalmitis so as to treat it immediatelyand ensure patient compliance on post-surgery medication and precautions to reduce the serious complications caused by late diagnosis and treatment of post-cataract endophthalmitis.

questions.text: Following a fall, a 54-year-old woman appears. She also has a facial palsy, according to reports. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
There are two close answers here: syringobulbia and syringomyelia

Syringomyelia does not have any cranial nerve involvement but syringobulbia does and thus causing the facial palsy in the above question.

questions.text: Following a car accident, a 27-year-old male arrives with chest discomfort and respiratory difficulty. His neck veins are distended, and his trachea is deviated to the right on examination. On the left lung field, breath sounds are absent, whereas on the right lung field, they are decreased. He has an 80/40 mmHg blood pressure and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. What is the MOST APPROPRIATE SINGLE NEXT STEP?

choices.text: Insertion of a cannula into the left second intercostal space
Insertiion of a cannula into the right second intercostal space
Insertion of a chest drain into the right mid-axillary line

questions.solution:
The features described is diagnostic of left sided tension pneumothorax

Tension Pneumothorax

Presentation

  • Acute respiratory distress
  • Hypotension
  • Raised jugular venous pressure
  • Tracheal deviation away from the pneumothorax side
  • Reduced air entry on affected side

Management of a tension pneumothorax

If strong clinical suspicion, give high-flow oxygen and insert large-bore cannula into second intercostal space in midclavicular line on side of pneumothorax

  • Do not wait for a chest X-ray if patient seriously compromised or cardiac arrest has occurred or if the diagnosis is clinically certain
  • Hiss of escaping air confirms diagnosis
  • Air should be aspirated until the patient is less distressed. Then interest a chest drain in mid-axillary line, leaving the cannula in place until you have finished and the underwater seal is bubbling satisfactorily

Comparing simple and tension pneumothorax

Simple pneumothorax Tension Pneumothorax
Trachea ↓ Trachea →
Expansion ↓ Expansion ↓
Precussion Note ↑ Precussion Note ↑
Breathe sounds → Breathe sounds →
Neck Veins ↑

PNEUMOTHORAX TYPES

Primary spontaneous pneumothorax

  • Occurs without an apparent cause

Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax

  • Occurs in presence of existing lung pathology e,g, COPD

Simple pneumothorax

  • Non-expanding collection of air around the lung

Tension pneumothorax

  • Expanding collection of air around the lung

    • Touch the posterior pharyngeal wall with suction catheter and look for gag reflex

If no stimulus cough Gag reflex is (-)ve

Note: Plantar reflex Spinal reflexes test are never done as they may be positive inspite of Brain stem death

questions.text: A 46 year old male presents to the hospital with painless swelling in front of the ear lobule. FNAC revealed it as pleomorphic adenoma. What will be treatment of choice in this patient:

  • Females, 4th decade

CF

    • Fixation to mastoid tip

2. Recurrence: Occurs when Enucleation or Inadequate removal done

questions.text: Which of the following statements about auditory ossicles is NOT true?

choices.text: Malleus and incus develop mainly from the first brachial arch
The foot plate of the stapes is held in the oval window by annular ligament
The incudostapedial joint is an example of a ball and socket joint
The head of the malleus is embedded in the fibrous layer of tympanic membrane

questions.solution:
• There are three ossicles in the middle ear-the malleus, incus and stapes.
  • The malleus has head, neck, handle (manubrium), a lateral and an anterior process. The head and neck of malleus are present in the attic while the manubrium of malleus is embedded in the fibrous layer of the tympanic membrane. The lateral process forms a knob
  • like projection on the outer surface of the tympanic membrane and gives attachment to the anterior and posterior malleal (malleolar) folds.
  • The incus has a body and a short process, both of which lie in the attic, and a long process which hangs vertically and attaches to the head of stapes.
  • The stapes has a head, neck, anterior and posterior crura, and a footplate. The footplate is held in the oval window by annular ligament.
  • There are two joints between the ossicles- incudomalleolar and incudostapedial joint. The incudomalleolar is a saddle joint whereas the incudostapedial joint is an example of a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: Antenatal ultrasound for a 26 year old primigravida at 22 weeks gestation suggests vasa previa. This type of presenatation is associated with an increased risk for?

choices.text: Torsion of the umblical cord and fetal death
Fetal exsanguination before labor due to blood loss

questions.solution:
VELAMENTOUS PLACENTA and Vasa Previa

  • VELAMENTOUS PLACENTA -The cord is attached to the membranes. The branching vessels traverse between the membranes for a varying distance before they reach and supply the placenta.
  • If the leash of blood vessels happen to traverse through the membranes overlying the internal os, in front of the presenting part, the condition is called vasa previa.
  • Rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding. As it is entirely fetal blood, this may result in fetal exsanguination and even death.
  • In the presence of fetal bleeding, urgent delivery is essential either vaginally or by cesarean section. The infant’s hemoglobin should be estimated and if necessary, blood transfusion be carried out. If the baby is dead, vaginal delivery is awaited.

questions.text: In a patient, Rinne test positive in both ears, Weber's lateralizes to the right. This implies:
questions.solution:
Interpretation of the Rinne test is as following-

  • Normally, AC is 2 times better than BC (+ve Rinne).
  • Conductive deafness, AC lesser than BC (–ve Rinne).
  • Sensorineural (SN) deafness, AC greater than BC [but, duration is reduced] (low +ve Rinne).

For Weber’s test

  • In conductive deafness, the sound is lateralized to deaf ear and in bilateral conductive loss to the deafer ear or it is centrally heard if both ears are equally deaf. It is because ambient noise does not disturb the diseased ear as much as the normal ear.
  • In sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), sound is lateralized to better hearing ear or is heard centrally if both ears are equally bad.
  • In normal ear, no lateralization of sound occurs.

For this patient, Rinne test positive in both ears indicates either hearing is normal or there is SNHL. Weber lateralizes to the right means that the left ear has SNHL. This cannot be conductive hearing loss of any side as Rinne is positive.

questions.text: Which of the following leads to a zonular cataract?
questions.solution: Cataract in young patients is usually secondary to eye trauma, uncontrolled diabetes, galactosemia, hypothyroidism, inborn error of copper metabolism and chronic hypocalcemia. Cataract is a well-known complication of hypoparathyroidism. The progression of cataract is usually slow in patients with primary hypoparathyroidism while cataracts due to secondary hypoparathyroidism develop rapidly. Pathogenesis of cataract in hypoparathyroidism is proposed as membrane damage due to low calcium levels in the aqueous humour.

questions.text: A 36 year old female presents to the hospital with abdominal pain. She is also taking medications for her gout. USG reveals stone in her kidney. What is the most common type of stone formed in gout patients:
questions.solution:
Types of Renal Stones

Ca Oxalate stones

  • Most common type of renal stones
  • Radiopaque
  • Risk factors
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Hyperoxaluria

Uric acid stones

  • Most common type of radiolucent renal stone

Risk factors

  • Cout
  • Lesch- Nyhan syndrome
  • Myeloproliferative disorders (due to increased breakdown of cells)
  • (Hypoxanthine Xanthine →Uric Acid)

Management Principles

If acidic stone - do alkalinisation of urine

  • If basic stone - do acidification of urine.
  • Acid combines with base & forms salt which is soluble is excreted in urine.
  • Plenty of fluids
  • Low purine diet
  • Acetazolamideis used for Alkalinisation of urine
  • Allopurinol - To block conversion of Hypoxanthine to xanthine & hence block formation of uric acid.

Struvite stones

  • Aka staghorn calculi / Triple phosphate stone (Ca, Mg, Nh4+, Phosphate)
  • MC in females because of short urethra (4cm)
  • Short urethra – Increased risk of UTI → Proteus → produces urease
  • Urease converts urea into ammonia – Ammonia gets precipitated
  • 3-5 minor calyces join major calyx and later forms pelvis, pelvic ureteric junction and then ureter
  • Struvite stone is very large & fills pelvic calyceal system and looks like staghorn (due to branching in stone) → very large silent destruction of kidney

Management

  • Sandwich Technique – PCNL (percutaneous nephrolithotomy) + ESWL (Extra corporeal shock wave lithotripsy)
  • To prevent recurrence of stone formation – Irreversible inhibitor of urease (AcetoxyHydroxamic acid )

Cystine stones

  • Seen in cystinuria
  • Radio Opaque (double sulphide bond)
  • Very Hard (not easily broken by ESWL)
  • Crystal – Benzene shaped Crystal (Hexagonal Crystal)
  • D – Penicillamine
  • a-MPG (Alpha-mercaptopropionyl glycine) (Alpha MPG>D -penicillamine) Alpha – MPG – Better tolerated

Xanthine stones

  • Seen in xanthinuria
  • Hypoxanthine – xanthine (Allopurinol can be used to block conversion of Hypoxanthine to xanthine)
  • Radiolucent
  • Brick-red in color
  • Lamination on cross section

questions.text: A 55 year old woman presents with complaints of post menopausal bleeding . On further investigations, a diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma is made. Staging of the tumor shows Stage III A. Which of the following options corresponds to Stage III A of endometrial carcinoma according to 2009 FIGO staging system?

choices.text: Tumor contained to the corpus uteri but has invaded less than half of myometrium.
Tumor invades the cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterus.
Tumor invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa and/or distant metastases.
Local and/or regional spread of tumor with invasion of serosa of the corpus uteri and /or adnexa.

questions.solution:
STAGING OF Ca ENDOMETRIUM

2009 FlGO staging system for carcinoma of the endometrium

Stagel Tumor contained to the corpusuteri

IA No orless than half myometrial invasion

IB Invasion equal to or more the half of the myometrium

Stage ll Tumor invades the cervical stroma but does not extend beyond the uterus

Stage lll Local and/or regional spread of tumor

IllA Tumor invades the serosa of the corpus uteri and /or adnexas

IIIB Vaginal and/or parametrial involvement

IIIC Metastases to pelvis and/or para-aorticlymphnodes

IIIC1 Positive pelvic nodes

IIIC2 Positive para-aortic lymph nodes with or without positive pelvic lymph nodes

Stage lV Tumor invades bladder and/or bowel mucosa and/or distant metastases

IVA Tumor invasion of bladder and/or bowel mucosa

IVB Distant metastases, including intra-abdominal metastases and or inguinal lymph nodes

questions.text: A 45 year old female complained of pain in her joints along with polyuria & polydipsia. She hasn’t passed the stools since last days & vomited thrice yesterday. Her blood tests revealed increased calcium levels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT)

  • Caused by increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) from abnormal parathyroid gland
  • More common in females
  • MC cause of PHPT – solitary adenoma (80% of cases)
    • MC location – inferior parathyroid
  • Increased PTH leads to hypercalcemia
  • Mechanism that can leads to hypercalcemia
    • Increased GI absorption of calcium
    • Decreased renal calcium clearance
    • Increased production of vitamin D3

Etiology

  • Familial predisposition
  • Exposure of low therapeutic ionizing radiation
  • Declining renal function with age
  • Alteration in the sensitivity of parathyroid gland to suppression – by calcium
  • Lithium therapy

Most cases of PHPT are sporadic

It is associated with – MEN-1, MEN 2A, isolated familial HPT, familial

HPT with jaw tumor syndrome

Clinical features

S/P Resorption

  • Radial side
  • Middle phalanx
  • 2nd / 3rd fingers

Skull – salt & pepper App.

Cystic lesion → haemorrhage → OFC (Osteitis cystica) → Brown Tumor (Hemosiderin)

  • Classical pentad
    • Kidney stone
    • Painful bones
    • Abdominal groans
    • Psychic moans
    • Fatigue over tones

  • Increased concentration of PTH – elevated immunoreactivePTH in asymptomatichypercalcemia
  • Decreased serum phosphate & increased 24 hours urinary calcium
  • Most widely used an accurate investigation for localization of parathyroid adenoma – Tc labelled Sestamibi scan
  • X-ray findings of hands
    • Subperiosteal resorption – most apparent on radial aspect of – middle phalanx of 2nd & 3rd finger
    • Bone cyst
    • Tufting of distal phalanges

Management

  • Basic principles of management

1. SERM (selective estrogen receptor modulator) or Bisphosphonates (IV ibandronate)

  • To decrease Ca2+ level
  • To increase bone mineral density

2. Parathyroidectomy

  • if patient has
  • Classical pentad (or)
  • Age <50 years

Steps in management of PHTP

1. Correction of hypercalcemia – by IV normal saline followed by forced diuresis with furosemide

2. Neck exploration

  • Single adenoma (80-85% cases) – Resection
  • Two adenomas (5% cases) – Resection
  • Hyperplasia of all 4 glands (10-15% cases)
    • Excision of 3 and half gland or
    • Excision of all 4 glands

Note

  • Accidentally removed parathyroid gland during thyroidectomy – should be auto transplanted into belly of sternocleidomastoid muscle, (PTG are broken into 1 mm pieces for placing into SCM)
  • Site of transplantation is marked with suture / clip.

questions.text: Keratosis obturans refers to:

choices.text: Desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus
Collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium
Foreign body in external auditory canal

questions.solution:
• KERATOSIS OBTURANS is accumulation of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Also called as canal wall cholesteatoma M/C in young patients.
  • Its clinical features include severe ear pain, mild to moderate conductive hearing loss with associated sinusitis or bronchitis.
  • For treatment, surgical removal under GA is preferred. Canal plasty is an option in recurrent cases. Mastoidectomy is done in cases with primary cholesteatoma of external canal. However, recurrence is quite common.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady with rheumatoid arthritis is experiencing dry eyes. A Schirmer's test reveals reduced tear production, whereas a rose Bengal stain reveals corneal ulcers. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Sjogren's syndrome

Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disorder affecting exocrine glands resulting indr mucosal surfaces. Sjogren syndrome may be seen alone (primary) or in associationwit other autoimmune diseases (secondary) such as rheumatoid arthritis, primarybiliary cirrhosis, or systemic lupus erythematosus.

As Sjogren's syndrome progresses, it becomes a systemic disease involving majororgans (lungs, kidneys, etc.) and may eventually evolve into a lymphoproliferativedisease - malignant Lymphoma. Note that sjogren's syndrome is much more common in females (ratio 9:1)

Features

dry eyes: keratoconjunctivitis sicca

  • Patients complain of itchy eyes, sandy feeling under their eyes (because ofdecreasec lacrimal production) dry mouth
  • Patients may complain of difficulty swallowing food vaginal dryness parotid enlargement
  • Bilateral enlargement of the parotid glands

Investigation

  • Schirmer's test will show decreased tear production
  • Rose Bengal stain will document corneal ulcerations
  • ANAs will be positive and specifically anti-Ro (SSA) and anti-La (SSB)
  • rheumatoid factor (RF) positive in nearly of patients

Management

  • There is no cure for sjogren’s syndrome. Artificial tears may help with the dry eyes.

questions.text: Over the last two days, a 50-year-old guy has developed a red, sensitive, and swollen left foot. He is unable to bear weight due to the severity of the pain. He had a myocardial infarction four weeks ago and is now suffering from heart failure. His cardiologist recently prescribed meds for him. Which of the drugs is most likely to blame for the swelling in his left foot?
questions.solution:
This man was likely prescribed furosemide to combat the fluid overload from the heart failure. Furosemide may raise uric acid levels and precipitate gout. Gout most commonly affects the metatarsophalangeal joint of the first toe but question writers will not make questions that obvious and often they may describe it as left foot swelling and pain. Other common precipitants of gout are:

  • Excessive amounts of alcohol
  • Thiazide diuretics like bendroflumethiazide

questions.text: A 36 year old female presents to the hospital with hematuria. She also informed that her USG last week revealed ovarian cyst. She is taking Amlodipine 10mg for her hypertension. On, IVP there is swiss- cheese appearance. What is the condition she is suffering from:
questions.solution:
ADPKD [Autosomal Dominant Polysctic Kidney Disease]

  • Invovlvement of chromosome 16, 4
  • Abnomral protein – Polycystin

Clinical Features

  • Usually presented on 3rd to 4th decade
  • MC – Hypertension (75% Adults & 25% Children)
  • Other Presentations
  • Polyuria
  • Nocturia
  • Hematuria
  • Nephrolithiasis
  • MC cause of death – Cardovascular disorders
  • CRF
  • Uusally in 5th to 6th decade
  • Management – Hemodialysis/Renal transplantation

Extra – renal manifestations of ADPKD

  • Polycystic Liver Disease (MC)
  • Cyst in Ovary, Pancreas, Spleen
  • Mitral Valve prolapses
  • Berry Aneurysm
  • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Arachnoid cyst
  • Cyst in seminal vesicle
  • In ADPKD, Cyst is not seedn in Lungs
  • In 8% of cases Arachnoid cyst is seen invoving brain

Investiations

  • IOC – CECT
  • On IVP
    • Spinder leg/Bell-Shpaedappearnace
    • Bubble Appearance
    • Swiss – Cheese Appearance

Management

  • TOC – Renal Transplantation
  • ROVSING’S Operation – Deroofing of Cyst in ADPKD
  • ROVSING’s Syndrome – Hyperextension of spiene in proudcues abdominal Pain, Nausea, Vomitting in horse shoe kidney
  • ROVSING Sign – Pain in right iliac fossa on pressing left iliac fossa

questions.text: Which of the following statement about tympanic membrane is false?

choices.text: Tympanic membrane is positioned at an angle of 55 degrees to the external auditory canal
IX cranial nerve’s tympanic branch supplies the medial part of tympanic membrane
The cone of light forms on anterosuperior quadrant
Pars tensa forms most of the tympanic membrane and is less mobile than pars flaccida

questions.solution:
• Tympanic membrane forms the partition between the external acoustic canal and the middle ear. It is obliquely set and as a result, its posterosuperior part is more lateral than its anteroinferior part.
  • Tympanic membrane comprises of two parts: Pars Tensa and Pars Flaccida.
  • Pars tensa forms most part of tympanic membrane. A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of malleus to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant.
  • Pars Flaccida (Sharpnell’s Membrane)is present above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and and the anterior and Posterior malleal folds (earlier called malleolar folds). It is not so taut and may appear slightly pinkish.
  • In terms of nerve supply of tympanic membrane, the lateral or outer surface’s anterior half is supplied by auriculotemporal nerve and posterior half by the vagus nerve (Arnold nerve). The medial or inner surface is innervated by Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson’s nerve)

Absent Cardiac Activity Present

questions.text: All of the following are treatment modalities for first degree haemorrhoids, except:

  • Fourth degree – bleeding + Permanent prolapse

Treatment

  • First degree haemorrhoids
    • Sitz batch
    • Dietary modification
    • Stool softener
    • High fiber diet

  • First degree, second degree and selected patients of third degree

    • Sclerotherapy (5% phenol in almond oil)

questions.text:
For the past 15 hours, a 32-year-old lady has been short of breath and has been feeling ill. An arterial blood gas test is performed.
PaO2 8.8 kPa
PaCO2 3.2 kPa
pH 7.50
Bicarbonate (HCO3-) 20 mmol/L
Normal Values:
PaO2 > 10 kPa
PaCO2 4.7-6 kPa
pH 7.35 – 7.45
Bicarbonate (HCO3-) 22-26 mmol/L
What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This woman has become acutely breathless from a pulmonary emboli. She is hypoxic and, as a reflex to this, is hyperventilating (as evidenced by the low PaCO2). As a result, she has developed an alkalosis.

The other options are much less likely to be the answer:

Diabetic ketoacidosis and methanol overdose → both causes acidosis. The scenario that was given is alkalosis

Panic attacks → This does cause acute alkalosis via hyperventilation (and therefore low PaCO2 and a high pH), but tends to happen in the absence of hypoxia rather than as a response to it (as in pulmonary embolism)

To understand this question, we have to go back to basics.

First, is the patient hypoxic?

  • the Pa02 > 10is normal

Second, is the patient acidaemic (pH<73.35) or alkalaemic (pH>7.45)

Third, what is the respiratory component: What has happened to the PaCO2?

  • PaCO2 > 6.0 kPasuggests a respiratory acidosis (or respiratory compensation for a metabolic alkalosis) PaCO2 < 4.7 kPasuggests a respiratory alkalosis (or respiratory compensation for a metabolic acidosis)

Fourth, what is the metabolic component: What is the bicarbonate level/base excess?

  • bicarbonate <22 mmol/l suggests a metabolic acidosis (or renal compensation for a respiratory alkalosis)
  • bicarbonate > 26 mmol/l suggests a metabolic alkalosis (or renal compensation for a respiratory acidosis)

In summary

She has developed respiratory alkalosis with very minimal renal compensation taking into account that renal compensation usually takes around 48 hours to manifest.

ARTERIAL BLOOD GASES, CASUES

METABOLIC ACIDIOSIS

  • Excess Production of Organic Acids
  • Ketoacidosis
  • Alcoholic
  • Violent convulsions
  • Excessive ingestion of Toxins
  • Aspirin
  • Methanol Alcohol
  • Excess loss of HCO3
  • Diarrhoea
  • Addison’s disease
  • Retention of Organic Acids
  • Renal insufficiency of Any Cause

METABOLIC ALKALOSIS

  • HCI loss
  • Vomiting
  • Excessive Administration of HCO3
  • Hypovolaemia
  • Increased Renal Excretion of Acid
  • Diuretic therapy
  • Secondary Hypoparathyroidism
RESPIRATORY ACIDOSIS RESPIRATORY ALKALOSIS
  • Airway obstruction
  • Aspiration
  • COPD
  • Respiratory center depression
  • Circulatory collapse
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Pulmonary oedema
  • Neurogenic causes
  • Cervical spine injury
  • Drugs (paralytic agents, organophosphates)
  • Restrictive effects
  • Haemothorax
  • Pneumothorax
  • Ascites
  • Anxiety – hyperventilation syndrome
  • Salicylate Intoxication
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Mechanical ventilation

questions.text:
Muscle weakness is present in a 60-year-old male. He has trouble walking for lengthy periods of time or climbing stairs. It's difficult to do things like stand up from a seated posture. He also has trouble swallowing some foods. His blood tests reveal the following:
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 149 U/L
Aspartatetransaminase (AST) 37 U/L
Alaninetransferase (ALT) 44 U/L
Creatinekinase 440 U/L
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 16 mm/h
What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The two top differentials here that one should think about is polymyositis and polymyalgia rheumatica.

Proximal muscle weakness and raised creatinine kinase points towards polymyositis.ESR is elevated in 50% of cases in polymyositis but correlates poorly with disease activity and response to therapy. In this stem, ESR is not elevated enough to consider polymyalgia rheumatica. Also, in polymyalgia rheumatica, creatinine kinase would not be raised. One of the criteria for the diagnosis of polymyalgia rheumatica is having an ESR >30 mm/h or CRP >6 mg/mLof which we do not see in this stem. Hence, the best answer here is polymyositis.

Polymyositis

Clinical Findings

  • First presents with difficulty with tasks that involve the proximal muscles:lifting objects, combing hair, getting up from the chair.
  • The weakness is usually symmetric and diffuse, involving the proximal musclesof the neck, shoulders, trunk, hips, and thighs, the lower limb muscles tendingto be clinically symptomatic first.
  • Fatigue, myalgia and muscle cramps may also be present.

Investigation:

  • Elevation of creatine kinase.
  • Aldolase levels may also be raised.
  • Autoantibodies:
    • Anti-Jo-1 antibodies. Note that these are more common in patients with polymyositis than in patients with dermatomyositis.
  • Muscle biopsy can be diagnostic.

Treatment

  • Involves steroids

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding this airway tube is incorrect?

questions.solution:
Nasopharyngeal airway
