questions.text: A 25 year old primigravida presents to the emergency department with left sided flank pain and spotting. She had a serum β- hCG of 800 mIU 3 weeks ago. Ultrasound reveals no intrauterine gestation. Diagnostic laparoscopy is performed which reveals 125 mL of blood in the pelvis. Placental tissue is recovered floating free in the peritoneal cavity. The pregnancy in this patient is most likely due to-
questions.solution:
• Outcomes of ectopic pregnancy include tubal rupture, tubal abortion, or pregnancy failure with resolution.
  • Tubal abortion is a common mode of termination, if implantation occurs in the ampulla or infundibulum. Muscular contraction enhances separation and facilitates its expulsion through the abdominal ostium.
  • Decidua is endometrium that is hormonally prepared for pregnancy, and the degree to which the endometrium is converted with ectopic pregnancy is variable. Thus, in addition to bleeding, women with ectopic tubal pregnancy may pass a decidual cast. This is the entire sloughed endometrium that takes the form of the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: A 43 years old female presented to the hospital with a rt. Sided breast lump. Mammography revealed microcalcifications. A diagnosis of cribriform type of DCIS has been made. What will be the treatment modality for the same:
questions.solution:
DCIS (ductal carcinoma insitu)

  • DCIS - high risk for progression to invasive ductal cancer
  • Ducts are present in breast of males and females – hence ductal carcinoma is common in both males and females
  • Lobules are seen in females only – hence lobular carcinoma is common in females exclusively.

Classification of DCIS is based on

  • Nuclear grade
  • Necrosis

Types of DCIS

Low grade DCIS

  • Cribriform
  • Papillary
  • Micropapillary

High grade DCIS

  • Solid
  • Comedocarcinoma

Investigations

  • On mammography – presence of microcalcifications due to necrosis
  • Most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of DCIS – MRI
  • Most sensitive investigation for diagnosis of microcalcification in DCIS – mammography

Treatment

  • Non palpable DCIS – excision by needle localization with specimen mammography
  • For low grade DCIS – Lumpectomy
  • For DCIS with limited disease – Lumpectomy + RT

  • Contraction stress test is part of antepartum surveillance. It is used to assess how oxytocin induced uterine contraction influence the fetus’ heart rate and tells the plausibility of doing a normal vaginal delivery

questions.text: An infant presents with constipation and signs of distal obstruction shortly after birth. The Xray abdomen reveals bowel distension wit multiple air fluid level. The mother also complains about the history of delayed passing of meconium. Which is the most common cause of lower intestinal obstruction in neonates
questions.solution:
• Hirshprung’s disease is most common congenital gut motility disorder with incidence of once in 5000 and is characterized by lack of ganglionic cells in submucosal and myenteric plexus of distal intestine
  • Infants affected with hirsprung’s disease present shortly after birth with constipation and signs of distal obstruction
  • About 90% of children with hirsprung’s disease failed to pass meconium in first 48 hours of life
  • In intususseption : barium enema shows claw sign. Sonography shows target sign
  • Pyloric stenosis is characterized by caterpiller or double sign in radiological examination
  • Peutz-jegerz is one of the polyposis syndrome characterized by multiple hamartomous polyps most commonly involving small intestine mainly ileum

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male was brought to Emergency by his buddies because he had a yellow sclera and skin discoloration. He's been suffering from flu-like symptoms and a non productive cough recently. A urine dipstick was used and found to be normal. His blood tests reveal the following:
Haemoglobin 129 g/dl
Reticulocytes 1.2%
Bilirubin 44 μmol/L
Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) 88
Alanine transferase (ALT) 24
Albumin 42
What is the SINGLE most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gilbert's syndrome is usually an autosomal recessive disorder and is a common cause of unconjugated hyperbilirubinaemia due to decreased UGT-1 activity which is the enzyme that conjugates bilirubin with glucuronic acid.

It may go unnoticed for many years and usually presents in adolescence with intermittent jaundice occurring during illness, physical exertion, stress or fasting. In this stem, the jaundice was precipitated by infection.

Investigations usually show a mildly raised serum bilirubin but the other LFTs remain within normal ranges as seen in this stem. FBC would show normal reticulocyte count -this helps distinguish Gilbert’s syndrome from other types of haemolysis. Urine dipsticks would be seen as normal as it is the unconjugated bilirubin that is high (not the conjugated bilirubin as would be seen in Dubin Johnson syndrome).

Remember, viral infections are common triggers for a rise in the bilirubin in patients with Gilbert's syndrome.

questions.text: A 20 year old male comes to the hospital with abdominal pain & fever. He also vomited thrice in the last 12 hours. On examination, Rovsings sign is positive. The patient is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Acute appendicitis

  • MC general surgical emergency worldwide
  • Seen in Young patient usually of 2nd decade

Etiopathogenesis

  • Luminal obstruction can be due to
    • Fecalith (MC cause)
    • Tumors (e.g. Carcinoid tumor)
    • Worm eggs (e.g. Ascaris eggs)
    • Fruit seeds

  • Mc site of perforation – Just distal to obstruction on antimesenteric border
  • Mc organism isolated after perforated appendicitis – Bacteroides fragilis>E.coli

Clinical features

  • Pain in peri-umbilical region – Shifting of Pain to right lilac fossa (Migratory Pain)
  • Most characteristic symptom of Acute appendicitis – Migratory pain ·
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea, Vomiting
  • Signs
    • Tenderness in right iliac fossa
    • Rebound tenderness
    • Elevated temperature

Lab investigations

  • Leucocytosis
  • Shift to left

Other named signs

DUNPHYS SIGN – Pain on coughing
ARON SIGN – Pain on gentile traction of right testes

ROVSINGS SING

  • Pain in right iliac fossa on pressing left iliac fossa
  • Most characteristic sign of acute appendicitis
ROVSING’S SYNDROME – In horseshoe kidney, hyper extension of spine causes pain, nausea, Vomiting. [Most characteristic sign]

OBTURATOR SIGN

  • Pain on internal rotation of right thigh over hip join
  • Obturator sign is positive in Pelvic Appendicitis
  • In Pelvic appendicitis, orientation of appendix is towards pelvis and in close relationship to rectum. So, abdominal sign are nto marked in Pelvic appendicitis Irritation of rectum – Diarrhea Irritation of ureter – Microscopic hematuria (>3RBCs/HPF)Delay in Dx – pt. presents with perforation

PASOAS SIGN

  • Hyper extension at right hip joint causes pain in right iliac fossa
  • Psoas sign is Positive in Retrocecal appendicitis

questions.text: Despite excessive drinking, a 40-year-old man is terribly thirsty. Diabetes mellitus and renal failure have been ruled out, leaving diabetes insipidus as the most likely diagnosis. The results of a fluid deprivation test and a vasopressin response assessment were consistent with central diabetes insipidus. What is the SINGLE most likely laboratory finding that lead to the conclusion?

choices.text: An increase in urine osmolality after administration of vasopressin
A decrease in urine osmolality after administration of vasopressin
An increase in plasma osmolality after administration of vasopressin
A decrease in plasma osmolality during fluid deprivation

questions.solution:
In diabetes Insipidus, one can expect excess fluid loss with urine. Urine osmolality would be low and plasma osmolality would be high.

After administration of vasopressin (desmopressin), an increase in urine osmolality is diagnostic for central (cranial) diabetes insipidus.

questions.text: A police officer is presented to your OPD with an history of a culprit hitting him in his left eye with fist. On examination, you found out that his anterior chamber is deep. He also reports a sudden loss of vision. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Lens dislocation is a rare complication of head injuries. However, trauma is the most common cause of lens dislocation . Blunt force in anteroposterior direction leads to equatorial expansion, which disrupts the zonular fibers and dislocates the lens .

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with a history of alcohol consumption is taken to the emergency room by a buddy from a nightclub. The patient abruptly collapsed on the dance floor, his body stiffening, jerking of his legs, and involuntary voiding, according to his buddy. He was drowsy and confused for some minutes after regaining consciousness before fully recovering. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
Generalised seizures usually have patients with a loss of consciousness (i.e. “collapsed”) while partial seizures may or may not have loss of consciousness depending if they are simple or complex. When both halves of the body (right and left) are involved, it is classified as generalised.

In this case, this patient’s seizure activity is due to alcohol abuse and therefore should follow guidelines on management related to seizures secondary to alcoholism. Stiffness is the tonic phase followed by twitching which is the clonic phase.

Myoclonic seizures are irregular jerks of the trunk or limbs which occur while the patient is conscious and lasts for less than a second. Most of us have this experience when we are falling asleep and suddenly jerk as if we fell down from a building. That is considered a normal phenomenon. Myoclonic seizures in an awake state are not normal and require specialist assessment.

Present After Birth Appears Disappears
STNR [Symmetric Tonic Neck Reflex] 4-6 months 8-12 months
Parachute Reflex 7-8 months Persists throughout life

questions.text: A 45-year-old habitual smoker presents to the outpatient department with a persistent cough and profuse purulent sputum. He had previously contracted the measles. On examination, finger clubbing is noticed, and auscultation reveals inspiratory crepitations. Tram track opacities can be seen on a chest X-ray. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
The history of smoking here is irrelevant as smoking does not appear to be anindependent risk factor but smoking cessation is important as per of the management if the patient does smoke.

The persistent cough and copious amount of purulent sputum are symptoms ofbronchiectasis. Measles is a childhood viral infection that is one of the aetiologies ofbronchiescatsis. Finger clubbing is not a specific sign but has been seen in bronchiectasislthough not very frequently. Inspiratory crepitations and a chest-x ray that showstramlines give a more specific picture pointing towards bronchiectasis. Although these are not diagnostic, the most probable diagnosis among the others is bronchiectasis. Onlya high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chest would give you the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis

Is the irreversible abnormal dilation of a small and medium sized bronchi, with chronic airway inflammation. It is associated with chronic sputum production chroniccough, recurrent acute chest infections, and airflow obstruction.

Aetiology

The disease is caused by chronic inflammation of the airways. It may therefore becaused by a large number of disorders which cause inflammation and infection, particularly conditions that facilitate infections, which therefore tend to be recurrentand more severe and so cause damage to the lungs. In general, the aetiology is either aone-off infectious insult or an underlying immune deficiency.

Post-infection: Childhood respiratory viral infections (measles, pertussis, influenza, respiratory syncytial virus), tuberculosis, bacterial pneumonia. Infection is the most common cause of bronchiectasis

Immunodeficiency: HIV infection. Always consider this as a cause in all ages, particularly if there have been serious, persistent or recurrent infections

Connective tissue disease. g. rheumatoid arthritis, Sj gren’s syndrome, systemic sclerosis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan’s syndrome

Toxic insults: Gastric aspiration, inhalation of toxic gases

Congenital defects: The most important one being cystic fibrosis

Clinical features

  • Persistent cough with purulent copious sputum production
  • Nonspecific respiratory symptoms including dyspnoea, chest pain andhaemoptysis. Bronchiectasis may progress to respiratory failure and corpulmonale - Coarse crackles are the most common finding, heard in early inspiration andoften in the lower zones
  • Large airway rhonchi (low-pitched snore-like sounds)
  • Wheeze may be present
  • Clubbing is found infrequently

Diagnosis

  • Usually made clinically, with high-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) chestfor confirmation.
  • A baseline chest x-ray should be done in all patients. Early chest x-ray findingsmay be normal in patients with bronchiectasis. Chest x-ray in advanced casesmay show 1 to 2 cm cysts, crowding of the bronchi (tramlines) or ring opacities. The main value of CXR is excluding other causes of symptoms.
  • Rx
    • Antibiotic for 10–14 days.
      • NTM infection: Macrolide with rifampin and ethambutol
    • Hydration
    • Mucolytic: Dornase (DNase)→Only for CF-related bronchiectasis
    • Bronchodilator
    • Hypertonic saline
    • Chest physiotherapy
    • Pulmonary rehabilitation
    • Refractory cases:
      • Resection of a focal area
      • Lung transplantation.

questions.text: Drowsiness and heavy breathing are seen in a 10-year-old child with type 1 diabetes mellitus. Her blood glucose level is 18 mmol/L. Her blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and she has dry mucous membranes. What is the ONE MOST SUITABLE NEXT STEP?
questions.solution: This child is likely suffering from diabetic ketoacidosis. An arterial blood gas at this time would be a good investigation of choice to determine the severity.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man was referred to secondary care after experiencing chronic back pain and tiredness for several months. Further investigations were conducted. A bone marrow biopsy revealed an abundance of plasma cells. What is the ONE DIGANOSIS that is most likely?
questions.solution:
A bone marrow biopsy with abundance of plasma cells is diagnostic for multiple myeloma.

Multiple Myeloma

Epidemiology:50–60 years of age. Multiple myeloma is the most common tumor arising within the bone.

Cytogenetic abnormalities: t(4;14) in which fibroblast growth factor receptor gene is translocated adjacent to the Ig heavy-chain gene; also, 13q deletions.

Clinical presentation of multiple myeloma

Symptoms:Bone pain, infection.

Signs:“Punched out” lesions of the skull seen on plain films are classic. Compression fractures of the vertebrae and pathologic fractures of the long bones are common, as is hypercalcemia.

Patients have renal failure associated with enlarged kidneys.

Complications of multiple myeloma

The most common bones involved are the vertebrae, skull, and ribs.

Bone pain due to expansion of marrow.

Lytic lesions in the bone due to the expansion of plasma cells, which can predispose to pathologic fractures. Production of IL-6 by neoplastic cells stimulates osteoclasts through the RANK ligand.

Hypercalcemia due to bone resorption.

Decreased levels of functional immunoglobin predispose patients to recurrent infections (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Escherichia coli).

Overproduction of the light chains, which collect in the kidney as casts in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting tubules. The light chains can cause renal insufficiency.

Amyloidosis due to the overproduction of light chains.

Important points regarding multiple myeloma

Almost 99% of multiple myelomas secrete Ig. There is no M spike in nonsecretory myelomas.

Approximately 60% of multiple myelomas produce IgG; 20–25% produce IgA; and 15–20% produce light chains only (κ or λ).

The main cause of death isinfection, and the second most common cause of death isrenal failure.

Approximately 20% of patients with multiple myeloma do not have a detectable M protein, but they do have free light chains in the urine.

Microscopic morphology of multiple myeloma (Figure 12-23 A and B)

More than 30% of bone marrow cells are plasma cells.

Accumulation of immunoglobins in plasma cells (Russell bodies).

questions.text: Which of the following evoked potential monitoring is least affected by anesthetic agents?

choices.text: Evoked response to posterior tibial nerve

questions.solution:
• Indications for intraoperative monitoring of evoked potentials (EPs) include surgical procedures associated with possible neurological injury: spinal fusion with instrumentation, spine and spinal cord tumor resection, brachial plexus repair, thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm repair, epilepsy surgery, and cerebral tumor resection.
  • Ischemia in the spinal cord or cerebral cortex can be detected by EPs.

Evoked potential monitoring

  • Non-invasive monitor of neural pathways
    • Sensory pathway →Sensory evoked potential
    • Motor pathway → motor evoked potential
    • Somato sensory pathway →somato-sensory evoked (Mixed nerve pathway) potential
  • Evoked potential monitoring is affected by anesthetic agents.

Note:-

  • N2O → Least affects evoked potential monitoring
  • Brain Stem Auditory Evoked Potential Monitoring
    • M/C evoked potential monitoring done
    • It is least affected by anesthetic agents

questions.text: A 32-year-old female gave birth to her first baby via normal vaginal delivery 4 weeks ago. She is exclusively breastfeeding the child and wants to continue breastfeeding up till one year. The woman read somewhere that lactation itself is not a foolproof method of contraception in postpartum period and asks for a better method of contraception. Which contraceptive method would you suggest in this case?

FOR POSTNATAL /LACTATIONAL AMENORRHEA [within 6 wks of delivery]

  • COCPs are not preferred as they can cause Lactational failure
  • Estrogen will cause glandular proliferation→ block lactiferous ducts
  • Progesterone only pills are preferred

questions.text: A 50 year old osteoarthritic female presents to the hospital. She complained of pain & tingling sensation along her inner aspect of forearm & hand. On examination, Halsted test was positive. The patient is having symptoms because of:
questions.solution:
THORACIC OUTLET COMPRESSION SYNDROME

  • Characterized by compression of subclavian vessels and nerves of brachial plexus at thoracic inlet, therefore it is a misnomer
  • MC in middle age females
  • It is of 2 two types
    • Neurogenic form because of compression of brachial plexus
    • Vascular form →because of compression of subclavian vessels
  • Compression in TOS is
    • Dynamic
    • So, best diagnosed by provocative tests

Thoracic outlet space is created by

  1. Clavicle
  2. Firstrib
  3. Subclavius muscle
  4. Anterior scalene muscle
  5. Costoclavicular ligament

Predisposing factors for TOS

  1. Cervical rib / Abnormal first rib / fibrous band
  2. Long transverse process of
  3. Osteoarthritis
  4. Pancoast tumor Cervicalhaematoma

Clinical Manifestation

  • In Neurogenic form
    • MC involved route value MC involved nerve - Ulnar nerve
    • Patients complains of Pain, Paraesthesia along inner aspect of forearm andhand
    • On examination, Atrophy of hypothenar and interossei muscles is seen
  • On Arterial compression - has Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paralysis, Paraesthesia
  • In Venous form-has Pain, Cyanosis, Edema

Diagnosed by provocative test

  1. Adson's test (Scalene test)
  2. Costoclavicular Test (military position or Halsted test)
  3. Hyperabduction test (Wright test)
  4. Roos test (Arm claudication test)
  • Numbness ‡ pain ishands with exercise

Management

  • >90% patients are of Neurogenic form - Treated Conservatively
  • improvement in postural sitting, standing and sleeping positions
  • Advice Muscle stretching and strengthening exercise Indications of surgical intervention are

Indications of surgical intervention are

  1. Failure of conservative mx.
  2. Progression of sensory or motor symptoms.
  3. Excessively prolonged ulnar or median nerve conduction velocity
  4. Narrowing/ occlusion of subclavian artery
  5. Thrombosis of axillary/ subclavian vein
  6. Presence of anatomical abnormality

questions.text: A patient is admitted for Caldwell-Luc operation. A resident doctor is studying the steps of the surgery. In this surgery, the nasoantral widow is made through-
questions.solution:
• In Caldwell-Luc’s Surgery, maxillary antrum is approached through an opening in its anterior wall by giving a the sublabial incision through canine fossa.
  • After entering the maxillary antrum, the pathology is removed. Later on the antrum is connected to the nose through a nasoantral window made via the inferior meatus.

Some of the conditions in which Caldwell-Luc Surgery is performed are-

  • Foreign bodies in the antrum
  • Dental cyst
  • Oroantral fistula
  • Fractures of maxilla
  • As an approach to pterygopalatine fossa (maxillary artery ligation/Vidian neurectomy) and ethmoids (transantral ethmoidectomy)

questions.text: Which of the following procedure for the correction of aphakia will lead to ‘Jack in Box Scotoma’?
questions.solution: Jack in box scotoma happens as a complication of using high powered spherical lens to correct aphakia. A high-powered spherical lens will cause a large ring scotoma . This will cause the patient to experience a ‘jack-in-the-box’ effect where objects viewed in the periphery will disappear as they enter this ring scotoma and then seem to suddenly reappear as they exit the scotoma.

questions.text: A 30 year old pregnant female delivered a baby wth a normal expulsion of an intact placenta. She starts bleeding per vaginally after 48 hours. On examination, she is hypotensive and a boggy mass is palpated on abdominal examination. USG shows tissues in uterine cavity. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Placenta succenturiate

  • One (usual) or more small lobes of placenta, size of a cotyledon, may be placed at varying distances from the main placental margin. A leash of vessels connecting the main to the small lobe traverse through the membranes.
  • Upon inspection of the placenta after explusion, deficiency in the membranes on the periphery point to a succenturiate lobe. ·
  • Retention of a succenturiate lobe after pregnancy may lead to the following complications- (1) Postpartum hemorrhage which may be primary or secondary (2) Subinvolution (3) Uterine sepsis (4) Polyp formation.
  • Treatment- When a succenturiate lobe is suspected, explore the uterus under general anaesthesia and remove the lobe.

  • Rectal involvement / Proctitis – Hall mark of UC (+in 100% pts)

questions.text: After tumbling down the stairs and breaking her rib, a 38-year-old lady is sent to A&E. Shortness of breath is a complaint she has. To rule out a rib fracture, a chest X-ray was taken. The chest X-ray revealed bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. There are vesicular breath sounds on auscultation. On inspection, she has red, sensitive sores on both of her shins. What is the ONE MOST LIKELY DISEASE?
questions.solution:
whenever you see the term “bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy” with a lesion on the shin, you should be thinking of Sarcoidosis.

The lesion on the shin is erythema nodosum which are blue or red lesions and are seen in people suffering from sarcoidosis.

The syndrome here is Lofgren syndrome which includes erythema nodosum, arthritis, and hilar adenopathy. Lofgren is a distinct sarcoid syndrome.

SARCODIOSIS

Sarcoidosis is a systemic disease of unknown cause, characterized histologically by the presence of nonspecific noncaseatinggranulomas in the lung and other organs.

Presentation

  • Up to 50% are asymptomatic (Chest X-ray for another indication reveals the diagnosis from hilar lymphadenopathy)
  • Involves almost any organ system, but pulmonary involvement is most common (around 90% of symptomatic patients)
  • Fatigue
  • Skin: Erythema nodosum
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Eyes: Uveitis
  • Kidneys: Stones

Acute presentation usually have the following:

  • Erythema nodosum
  • Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
  • Fever
  • Polyathralgia

There are two distinct sarcoid syndromes with acute presentation

  • Lofgren syndrome includes:
    • Erythema nodosum
    • Arthritis
    • Hilar adenopathy
  • Heerfordt-Waldenstrom syndrome, which described
    • Fever
    • Parotid enlargement
    • Uveitis
    • Facial palsy

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray shows bilateral hilaradenopathy
  • Bloods:
    • Elevation in angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) can be seen in of patients with sarcoidosis (but remember that ACE should not be used diagnose sarcoidosis. ACE levels are nonspecific but can be used to follow the course of the disease.)
    • Abnormalities in liver function tests are seen in of patients
    • Pulmonary function test may show a restrictive pattern
    • Calcium levels (Hypercalcaemia can occur due to increased circulation of vitamin D produced by macrophages)
  • Definitive diagnosis is by biopsy of suspected tissue which shows noncaseating granulomas. This can be from skin, lymph nodes, conjunctiva or lung.

questions.text: Among which of the following, Christmas appearance is observed?
questions.solution: Christmas Appearance is an exclusively ophthalmic change which is observed as a complication of Myotonic Dystrophy. These are not generally visually significant. The needle shaped polychromatic peptide crystals will be multi-coloured in appearance and they’ll be present in the cortex or nucleus of the lens.

questions.text: Peripheral paresthesia, slight shortness of breath, and tiredness are reported by a 46-year-old vegan. She has angular stomatitis and a sore red tongue, according to the examination. On a blood film, what is the SINGLE most likely cell type to be seen?
questions.solution:
Angular stomatitis is a known sign for iron deficiency anaemia however vitamin B12 deficiency is sometimes responsible for angular stomatitis, and commonly occurs together with folate deficiency The appearance of the tongue in vitamin B12 deficiency is described as "beefy" or "fiery red and sore".

Peripheral paresthesia is also a known symptom of vitamin B12.

Vitamin B12 deficiency has RBC changes which include oval macrocytosis

questions.text: A 26-year-old footballer passes out during a game and is taken to the hospital by ambulance. During the initial evaluation, his respiratory rate was 14 per minute, his pulse was 84 beats per minute, and his blood pressure was 115/80 mmHg. He's drenching himself in sweat and muttering strange words. What is the SINGLE most appropriate next course of action?
questions.solution:
The collapse could be due to hypoglycaemia. Check venous or capillary blood with glucose oxidase strip would be an appropriate first step before taking him for a CT scan or any other investigation. It is fast, easy and if hypoglycaemia is the cause, it can be quickly reversible.

Hyopglycaemia

Always exclude hypoglycaemia in any patient with coma, altered behaviour, neurological symptoms, or signs

Causes

  • Commonest cause is a relative imbalance of administered versus required insulin or oral hypoglycaemic drug. This results from
    • Exercise
    • Insufficient or delayed food intake
    • Excessive insulin administration

Other causes are:

  • Alcohol (in addition to alcohol directly causing hypoglycaemia, the features of hypoglycaemia may be mistaken for alcohol intoxication or withdrawal)
  • Addison’s disease
  • Insulinomas
  • Liver failure
  • Malaria

Common features:

Plasma glucose is normally maintained at 3.6-5.8mmol/L. Cognitive function deteriorates at levels<3.0mmol/L, but symptoms are uncommon >2.5mmol/L

  • Sweating
  • Pallor
  • Tachycarida
  • Palpitations
  • Hunger
  • Trembling
  • Altered or loss consciousness
  • Fitting
  • Coma

Diagnosis

  • Venous or capillary blood with glucose oxidase strip (BMG)
  • If <3.0 mmol/L, take a venous sample for a formal blood glucose level, but do not delay treatment

questions.text: Which of the following type of cataract is observed in Type 1 Diabetes?
questions.solution: Snowflake cataracts are a rare type of cataract which occurs as a long term complication of Diabetes. It progresses quickly and morphologically appears like a snowflake.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an indication for myringotomy in acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM)?

choices.text: Bulging tympanic membrane with acute pain
Incomplete resolution with antibiotic with persistence of symptoms of pain

questions.solution:
• In myringotomy, an incision is given in the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of Myringotomy in ASOM are-

  • Tympanic membrane bulging and there is acute pain
  • Incomplete resolution with antibiotics and patient complains of persistent deafness
  • Persistent effusion >12 weeks
  • ASOM with facial nerve palsy

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought to emergency with clubbing and cyanosis. Patient’s mother the said, child usually sits during cyanotic episodes. Ecocardiogram confirms congenital heart disease. Chest X-ray of disease is shown below. Which of the following treatment plays no role in treatment of cyanotic spell of the patient ?
questions.solution:
From mention question and following image we can diagnose it is case of tetralogy of fallot. The presentation of child squatting during his cyanotic episodes is termed Tet spells. Xray shows boot shaped heart.

Treatment Includes

  1. Moist O2 inhalation
  2. Inj. Sodium Bicarbonate
  3. Morphine
  4. Ketamine
  5. A agonists (Phenylephrine) .
  6. β blockers (Propranolol)
  7. Squatting or knee chest position helps in aborting cyanotic spell
  • No role of Calcium & Isoprendaline (b agonist) in the treatment of cyanotic spell

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the emergency with severe back pain that radiates down his legs, as well as urine retention and incontinence. Perineal sensory loss is discovered during the examination. What is the ONE inquiry that is the MOST APPROPRIATE?
questions.solution:
This is a classic example of cauda equina syndrome. It is a serious neurologic condition in which damage to the cauda equina causes loss of function of the nerve roots of the spinal canal below the termination (conus medullaris) of the spinal cord. Any lesion which compresses or disturbs the function of the cauda equina may disable the nerves although the most common is a central disc prolapse.

Investigation of choice is an MRI.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding color blindness, except?

choices.text: Ganglion cells are responsible for color vision processing
Human eyes are more sensitive to Red

questions.solution:
• Color blindness - More common in males than in female because the genes that produce photopigments are carried on the X chromosome.
  • Fovea is blue blind.
  • Ganglion cells are the cells mainly responsible for colour vision processing.
  • Human eyes are most sensitive to green colour
  • Achromatopsia is due to lesion in V8 > V4 area of occipital cortex
  • Primary colours : Red , Blue, Green

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding retrocochlear sensorineural hearing loss except:
questions.solution:
• Recruitment is a phenomenon of abnormal growth of loudness. The ear which does not hear low intensity sound begins to hear greater intensity sounds as loud or even louder than normal hearing ear.
  • Thus, a loud sound which is tolerable in normal ear may grow to abnormal levels of loudness in the recruiting ear and thus becomes intolerable.
  • The patients with recruitment are poor candidates for hearing aids. Recruitment is typically seen in lesions of the cochlea (e.g. Meniere's disease and presbycusis) and thus helps to differentiate a cochlear from a retrocochlear sensorineural hearing loss.
